So during this #BlackHistoryMonth  —which starts today—and throughout the year, what’s important to remember as we celebrate the milestones and achievements of the Black community, is that Black history is American history. (5/5)

I am deeply honored that the people of Georgia at this defining moment in American history chose a different vision for our state and nation as we continue to address the greatest crisis of our lifetimes. (4/5)

This history is not lost on me: today, a child of coastal Georgia serves as the 11th Black senator in our nation’s history, the first Black senator to represent Georgia, and the first Black Democratic senator to be elected in the South. (3/5) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtJZaZfXcAERrcv.jpg

Dr. King, & those brave men and women who worked & marched alongside him, weren’t just fighting to improve the lives of Black Americans. They pushed every American to appeal to the better angels of their nature, and opened the door of possibility & promise for a new future.(2/5)

Our country is defined by a struggle to make its foundational moral witness more authentic by building a more perfect union that includes us all. That story and struggle cannot be told completely without reference to people of African descent. #BlackHistoryMonth2021 (1/5) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtJZ4kdXIAABRTK.jpg

As we mark the start of #BlackHistoryMonth, we celebrate & honor the contributions of Black Americans who have shaped our country. Black history is American history—and it must be recognized this month and every month while we continue our fight to achieve equal justice for all.

I was sent to Washington to fulfill my promises and serve the needs of my constituents.  In recognition of that, I moved swiftly to co-sponsor a Constitutional Amendment that imposes term limits on all members of Congress. 

Read my latest op-ed: 
https://www.atchisonglobenow.com/voices/we-need-congressional-term-limits/article_cfbd7afa-64ce-11eb-a268-afccde5e2aad.html

I'm proud to co-sponsor @RepRalphNorman's Constitutional Amendment that imposes term limits on all members of Congress. If we are serious about draining the swamp in Washington, term limits should be one of our top priorities. https://twitter.com/RepRalphNorman/status/1354064804521107459 QT @RepRalphNorman Term limits ought to apply to:

Every.

Single.

Member of Congress.

Including me.

That is why I am proud to announce that I have proposed a Constitutional Amendment that would limit the number of terms individuals can serve in the House or Senate.

En el primer mes del nuevo Congreso radiqué tres de mis medidas pilares para fomentan el trabajo, y que son herramientas para combatir la pobreza y dan un respiro a individuos y sus familias con condiciones de salud que le afectan generar ingresos suficientes para vivir. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKYLEFWMAMBvJ7.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKYLEFXcAA7Xco.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKYLEJXAAAEQqW.jpg

Radiqué junto a @RitchieTorres, @StaceyPlaskett, @RepAmata & @RepDarrenSoto el HR 537, para extender el SSI a los residentes de #PuertoRico. Este es el único programa federal de apoyo de ingresos dirigido a familias con menores discapacitados. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKO0kuXcAIr4ox.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKO0rWXIAACY8_.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKO0yEXcAQluWG.jpg

También presentamos el HR 105, el Earned Income Tax Credit Equity for Puerto Rico Act, que podría significar un crédito anual combinado entre $300 a $8,500 entre la versión federal y la local restablecida en el 2019; estos fondos impactarán a más de 300,000 contribuyentes. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKD6qcXIAM9vhZ.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKD6vlW8AIGLCu.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKD62lXUAE8hHG.jpg

El CTC beneficiaría a cerca de 355,000 familias y 404,000 niños, lo que representaría $300 millones anuales. Durante el pasado término del Congreso, se votó extender las condiciones bajo el cual el CTC aplicaría en #PuertoRico. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKC7h5XYAIk84W.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKC7kEWMAgXUdV.jpg

Radiqué el HR 106, para extender a #PuertoRico el Crédito por Menor (CTC) en las mismas condiciones que se aplica en los estados, permitiendo que las familias trabajadoras con 1 o 2 hijos puedan ser elegibles para recibir un crédito contributivo federal de hasta $2,000 por hijo. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKCp-EWMAYvTUN.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKCp_QXYAAAq1R.jpg

Ahora en conferencia de prensa hablándoles sobre las tres medidas pilares que radicamos el primer mes en el Congreso para allegar ayudas federales a padres, trabajadores, adultos mayores y menores con condiciones especiales.

@KevinSLeahy ergo, the coal fleet CF could only fall and the gas fleet CF could only rise.  Price made the inevitable happen sooner, but it was still inevitable.

@KevinSLeahy Yes - the construction had already happened by then.  The point I made in the 2008 article I posted to was that if you looked at that reserve margin in the CCGT fleet then and simply increased to the level of the coal fleet, coal was dead in the water.

@KevinSLeahy And to the point I make later in this thread, I don't dispute that lower NG costs shifted dispatch of existing assets.  But the new asset construction + retirement of old coal made the transition inevitable.  Falling NG prices just affected the timing.

@KevinSLeahy There are a few exceptions, but look at capacity additions over the last 20 years.  Other than a few small spots, private markets long ago concluded that $2500/kW power with $15/MWh operating costs wouldn't pencil.

Words matter.  Their words kept their employees from transitioning sooner.  They kept politicians in the dark longer.  They slowed the transition to cheaper, cleaner energy.  Let us not continue that mistake any longer.  /fin

That issue goes down a rabbit-hole of IOU rate making rules, but suffice to say that no one in the industry was blind to the fact that the coal fleet was aging out and being replaced with cheaper, cleaner alternatives.  But some chose to publicly deny that truth.

So did state utility regulators BTW.  I recall convos with several saying that because the coal fleet opex had been capitalized, they were working with coal operators to keep them running as long as possible, lest those capital costs had to be brought forward in customer rates.

And so as those newly constructed, lower marginal operating costs ran more hours out of every day, the coal plants ran fewer.  This was, by the way, the basic investment thesis of those plants.  And again, the rest of the industry understood that dynamic.

To be sure, cheap gas and renewables did make a difference.  But only because once those new, cleaner plants were built, they were more economic to run than the zombie coal plants sitting in the same markets.

After all, if this was just exogenous cause, then the CEOs are blameless.  The reality is that while they were raiding pensions and boosting their compensation, coal miners and workers were losing out, while being told by their bosses that things would be fine.

And yet we still see articles suggesting that the coal industry would have been fine but for factors beyond their control.  That's not true!  But claiming that it's true absolves coal industry leaders from their responsibility in this transition.
I wrote about this over a decade ago, and none of what I said was particularly controversial among my colleagues in the power sector.  https://grist.org/article/beyond-coal/
Those zombie plants kept running for a long time, but it was just a matter of time before they were going to hit end of life.  The money was flowing to gas combined cycle and renewables.

But the Clean Air Act grandfathered those old, dirty plants into compliance.  The result was a steadily aging coal fleet as the private market shifted their dollars towards more productive investments.

Coal is only cheap if we're willing to let it be dirty.  Get rid of scrubbers, baghouses, stop caring about acid rain and asthma and you can build a cheap coal plant.  We haven't tolerated that since the CAA.  Thankfully.

There is this narrative that coal is cheap, and would still be dominant but for falling natural gas prices and clean energy tax credits.  That simply isn't true.  Coal hasn't been cheap since the Clean Air Act was passed.  It's been slowly dying for decades.
